It appears that the bracelet may have been deliberately destroyed and the pieces buried near an ancient Celtic settlement. \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdMaybe the owner of the bracelet lived in the village, the traces of which have been recorded in the same place,\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd Kotowicz told <a href="http://scienceinpoland.pap.pl/en/news/news,404230,valuable-archaeological-discovery-near-sanok.html" target="_blank"><em>Science and Scholarship in Poland</em></a>. The Celts arrived in the area in the middle of the third century B.C. from the Carpathian Mountains to the south. Saraceni</name>    <email>saraceni@verizon.net</email>   </author>   <summary type="html"><div class="feed-description"><p><img class="caption" style="margin-right: 15px; float: left;" title="(Stephen Leslie)" src="images/News/1503/Britain-Genetic-Map.jpg" alt="Britain-Genetic-Map" width="355" height="414" />OXFORD, ENGLAND\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdResearchers have developed a map of the United Kingdom based upon genetic variation in the late 1800s, when people were less likely than today to migrate far from the region of their birth. Donnelly and his team took samples from more than 2,000 Britons of European ancestry who lived in rural areas, and whose grandparents were all born in the same region. The team found 17 different groups based upon this DNA, and these groups matched the grandparents\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd geographic locations. The team also analyzed the genomes of more than 6,000 people from continental Europe to trace their ancestors\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd contributions to the Britons\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd ancestry, such as the Anglo-Saxons, who moved from present-day Denmark and Germany into Britain after the departure of the Romans and interbred with the local residents. \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdThe patterns we see are extraordinary. The genetic effects we\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdre looking at are the result of, probably, thousands of years of history,\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd Peter Donnelly, director of the Wellcome Trust Centre for Human Genetics, told <a href="http://www.nature.com/news/uk-mapped-out-by-genetic-ancestry-1.17136" target="_blank"><em>Nature News</em></a>. Saraceni</name>    <email>saraceni@verizon.net</email>   </author>   <summary type="html"><div class="feed-description"><p><img class="caption" style="margin-right: 15px; float: left;" title="(Ran Barkai)" src="images/News/1503/Israel-Paleolithic-Scrapers.jpg" alt="Israel-Paleolithic-Scrapers" width="710" height="270" /></p> <p>TEL AVIV, ISRAEL\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdFat residue has been detected on flint tools unearthed near a 500,000-year-old elephant rib bearing clear cut marks at the Revadim site in southern Israel. \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdNothing is for sure in archaeology. Based on the time, the culture, the behavior and the assemblage, we assume it was <em>Homo erectus</em>,\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd Ran Barkai of Tel Aviv University told <a href="http://www.haaretz.com/life/archaeology/.premium-1.647790" target="_blank"><em>Haaretz</em></a>. This is the first time that animal remains have been found on an Acheulian biface and a scraper, a discovery that was made possible by Fourier Transform InfraRed (FTIR) spectra technology. It is not known if the animal had been hunted or scavenged, however. \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdNot all agree that prehistoric men ate elephants. Some think that prehistoric men who weren\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdt <em>Homo sapiens sapiens</em> had some sort of problem. They have difficulty accepting that they could hunt and eat elephants. I am confident they\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdre wrong,\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd Barkai said. Saraceni</name>    <email>saraceni@verizon.net</email>   </author>   <summary type="html"><div class="feed-description"><p><img class="caption" style="margin-right: 15px; float: left;" title="(Brooklyn Museum Archives, Public Domain)" src="images/News/1503/Pompeii-tourist-photos.jpg" alt="" width="260" height="240" />LONDON, ENGLAND\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdZena Kamash of <a href="http://www.alphagalileo.org/ViewItem.aspx?ItemId=150892&amp;CultureCode=en" target="_blank">Royal Holloway, University of London</a>, examined nineteenth- and early twentieth-century lantern slides of Pompeii taken by tourists, and compared them to modern-day photographs posted by travelers on the Internet. She found that the images are remarkably similar\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdthey contain few people, despite the crowds that are drawn to the ancient city, even in the age of the selfie. \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdI think we have a very powerful imagined idea of what an ancient city should be like, which is a romantic empty ruin that stands in mute testament to the past. This is the view that has come down to us from the earliest drawings of archaeological sites and through the quiet, empty photos that we find in the lantern slide collection,\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd Kamash said in a press release. \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdIn the case of Pompeii, I think this is particularly strong because we all know the tragic story of its destruction and devastation by Vesuvius erupting in A.D. 79\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdthe silent plaster casts of the bodies trying to flee seem to really capture people\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds imagination and bring home to visitors the emptiness, death and loss suffered by the city all that time ago,\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd she concluded. To read in-depth about work at one of Pompeii's most iconic buildings, see "<a href="http://www.archaeology.org/issues/124-1403/features/1813-pompeii-saving-the-villa-of-the-mysteries">Saving the Villa of the Mysteries</a>."</p></div></summary>   <content type="html"><div class="feed-description"><p><img class="caption" style="margin-right: 15px; float: left;" title="(Brooklyn Museum Archives, Public Domain)" src="images/News/1503/Pompeii-tourist-photos.jpg" alt="" width="260" height="240" />LONDON, ENGLAND\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdZena Kamash of <a href="http://www.alphagalileo.org/ViewItem.aspx?ItemId=150892&amp;CultureCode=en" target="_blank">Royal Holloway, University of London</a>, examined nineteenth- and early twentieth-century lantern slides of Pompeii taken by tourists, and compared them to modern-day photographs posted by travelers on the Internet. Saraceni</name>    <email>saraceni@verizon.net</email>   </author>   <summary type="html"><div class="feed-description"><p>VARNA, BULGARIA\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd<a href="http://archaeologyinbulgaria.com/2015/03/17/archaeologists-dig-up-ancient-skeleton-under-odessos-fortress-wall-in-bulgarias-varna/" target="_blank"><em>Archaeology in Bulgaria</em></a> reports that the skeleton of a tall man was unearthed during rescue excavations near the St. Nikolay Church in Varna by archaeologists from the Varna Museum of Archaeology. Part of the skeleton, dated to the late fourth century or early fifth century A.D., is located beneath the fortress wall of the ancient city of Odessos. The man may have died in an accident during the construction of the ancient wall, and his remains laid in the deep pit, which was dug as a construction ditch for the foundation of the wall. \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdIt is possible that someone used the pit, which had been dug up [for construction purposes], to bury the body,\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd said lead archaeologist Valeri Yotov.&nbsp;</p></div></summary>   <content type="html"><div class="feed-description"><p>VARNA, BULGARIA\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd<a href="http://archaeologyinbulgaria.com/2015/03/17/archaeologists-dig-up-ancient-skeleton-under-odessos-fortress-wall-in-bulgarias-varna/" target="_blank"><em>Archaeology in Bulgaria</em></a> reports that the skeleton of a tall man was unearthed during rescue excavations near the St. Nikolay Church in Varna by archaeologists from the Varna Museum of Archaeology. Saraceni</name>    <email>saraceni@verizon.net</email>   </author>   <summary type="html"><div class="feed-description"><p><img class="caption" title="(LMih)" src="images/News/1503/Celtic-Bratislava-Castle.jpg" width="320" height="213" style="margin-right: 15px; float: left;" />BRATISLAVA, SLOVAKIA\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdThe fate of a Celtic archaeological site discovered during the construction of underground garages at Bratislava Castle, home of the Slovak National Museum, is still unclear after 12 hours of discussion yesterday. An expert commission recommended preserving and exhibiting the site in situ. One of its features is located under a replica of an eighteenth-century winter riding school that could be used for public events. \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdThese negotiations were certainly not easy. Saraceni</name>    <email>saraceni@verizon.net</email>   </author>   <summary type="html"><div class="feed-description"><p><img class="caption" style="margin-right: 15px; float: left;" title="(Maloff1)" src="images/News/1503/Leluh-Ruins-Kosrae-Micronesia.jpg" alt="" width="320" height="213" />PERTH, AUSTRALIA\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdThe royal tombs in the ancient city of Leluh, located just off the mainland of Kosrae, a Micronesian island, may be older than had been previously thought. The city was home to high chiefs and others from about 1250 until the mid-nineteenth century, when whalers, traders, and missionaries started to arrive on the island. Leluh features canals and walled compounds built of basalt, and temporary, pyramid-shaped tombs, or <em>saru</em>, built from living coral. Historical sources indicate that when Kosraean high chiefs died, their bodies were rubbed with coconut oil and then wrapped in mats and cords to be buried in the <em>saru</em> for up to three months. The bones were later exhumed, cleaned, and reburied in a hole on the nearby reef. \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdToday, the ancient tombs of the royal burial complexes are one of the few parts of the ancient Leluh site that remain intact. Much of the historical site is overgrown by the tropical forest and has succumbed to hundreds of years of tropical weather and tidal inundation, and some parts of the site have been dismantled and reused in modern construction,\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd Zoe Richards of the Western Australian Museum told <a href="http://www.livescience.com/50135-coral-tombs-leluh-700-years-old.html" target="_blank"><em>Live Science</em></a>. Uranium-thorium dating of the coral in the tombs shows that they could have been built as early as the fourteenth century, or about 300 years earlier than previously thought. \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdTo extract and translocate the amount of coral used to build the <em>saru</em>, as well as the structures and walls throughout Leluh, would have required a highly structured social order that could organize and demand significant labor and logistical support from the population,\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd she added. Saraceni</name>    <email>saraceni@verizon.net</email>   </author>   <summary type="html"><div class="feed-description"><p><img class="caption" style="margin-right: 15px; float: left;" title="(Rishi Aryal)" src="images/News/1503/Maya-papaya-domestication.JPG" alt="" width="298" height="269" />CHAMPAIGN, ILLINOIS\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdA genetic study of the sex chromosomes of the papaya plant suggests that the hermaphrodite version of the plant, which produces the fruit desired by growers, was first cultivated some 4,000 years ago by the Maya. Today, growing hermaphrodite papaya plants is costly and inefficient because farmers cannot tell which seeds are hermaphrodites until the plant has flowered.
